THE NEWS r=ED LKITER
VOL. XV, NO. 13.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 9, 1911.

DR. HOWELL RESIGNS AS DEAN

TRIANGULAR DEBATE LEAGUE

LACROSSE SCHEDULE COMPLETED

GAINING SECOND WIND

Retains Chair of Physiology, However,
and His Place is Taken by
Professor Williams.

Hopkins, Gettysburg and Washington
and Lee to Meet in Platform Contests Under New Agreement.

Indians Take Last Open Date, Assuring
Unusually Interesting Season.

Committee Renewing Efforts to Complete Second Million by a Vigorous
Campaign.

After eleven years of service
Dr. William Henry Howell has resigned as Dean of the Medical
School. His resignation has been
accepted by the trustees. Dr. J.
Whitridge Williams, professor of
obstetrics, has already taken up Dr.
Howell's duties. The latter will,
however, retain the chair of physiology which he has held since
1894.
The announcement of the resignation does not come as a surprise,
as the intimate friends of the dean
have known for some time that he
was seriously contemplating resigning. The combined duties of
the two positions were felt by Dr.
Howell to be too exacting, and he
tendered his resignation in order
to have more time to devote to his
work as professor of physiology.
President Remsen stated that he
was sorry to lose Dr. Howell, but
that he would continue on the staff.
Dr. Howell is a Baltimorean by
birth and received his preliminary
education in the public schools of
Baltimore. He received his bachelor's and doctor's degrees from
Hopkins, and in 1888 was appointed associate professor of
physiology. In the early nineties
he served on the staffs of the University of Michigan and Harvard
University, but returned to Hopkins in 1894 to become professor
of physiology. In 1899 he was
made dean.
Dr. Williams is also a Hopkins alumnus and is president of
the alumni association. He received his degree of doctor of
medicine, however, from the University of Maryland. He has spent
several years abroad and since 1889
has been collected with the medical
school. Dr. Williams is an attractive lecturer and is noted for the
amusing incidents and anecdotes
from his own personal experience
which lie intersperses in his explanations to his classes.

Additional opportunities for intercollegiate debating will be afforded Hopkins students by the inauguration this year of a triangular
league between this University,
Gettysburg College and Washington and Lee University.
Last year's victory at Lexington completed the series in which
Hopkins and Washington and Lee
had been engaged, and left both
institutions free to arrange new
contests. Dr. French and the committee corresponded with a number
of colleges with a view to entering
some kind of a triangular agreement. The expense of sending a
team far from Baltimore prevented
contests with some institutions,
while others were already engaged
in leagues among themselves.
In the selection of Gettysburg
as one of the opponents, its intimate
relations with Hopkins in the past
were taken into account. With the
single exception of Yale, Gettysburg has sent more graduates to
pursue advanced studies here than
has any other college. Washington and Lee was taken on largely
because of the desire of the defeated Virginians for an opportunity for revenge.
One difficulty in arranging the
terms of the agreement arose from
the desire of the Washington and
Lee authorities to put their law
students on the team. Both of the
other schools wished to limit the
contest to undergraduates and objected to meeting the law men.
The usual arrangements of triangular debates will govern the
contests. Each institution will be
represented by two teams of three
men each, one of which will debate
at home and the other abroad.
Thus each college debates both of
the others each year. The same
question is argued at all three institutions on the same night, and
each school upholds both sides, the
affirmative by one team and the
negative by the other.
New interest will doubtless be
taken in intercollegiate debating
here as a result of the new system.
Six places will be open to speakers
instead of three as heretofore, and
there must be twice as many alternates and advisers. This will demand the development of new debaters and will test the ability of
the undergraduates on the platform. More candidates for the
debating teams must apply in order
to turn out two winning teams.

The Dance.

The date of the second of the
series of dances to be given by the
Cotillion Club, which was announced for February 3rd, has been
changed to Saturday, January 28th.
The third dance will be given
Saturday, April 22nd. , It is hoped
that as many men as possible will
make a point of attending these
dances , and help to make them a
success.

The last open date on the lacrosse schedule, Saturday, April 22,
has now been filled. Manager
Makel has made arrangements with
the Carlisle Indians for a game to
be played at Homewood, and this
game completes the schedule.
The Indian game will come on the
Saturday before the Swarthmore
game and it is in a way significant
that the Indians are considered not
too strong to be played only 4. week
before the game which will in all
probability decide the intercollegiate championship of the United
States. Hopkins has games sched'tiled with three of the four teams
of the northern division of the
league and victories over these
teams are practically certain to include a victory over the champions
of this division. This schedule
with the northern team is rather
unusual for Hopkins. We play
Harvard regularly when their team
comes south in the spring, but
Cornell and Columbia have not
played in Baltimore for several
years.
, There will be only one disappointment for lacrosse enthusiasts
in Baltimore this year—the lack of
a game between the 'Varsity and
Mt. Washington. The Mt. Washington game always arouses great
interest and many will be sorry
not to have it this year.
The schedule this year is very
early, owing to the chancing of
the league schedule. Heretofore
we have played Swarthmore as the
last game in the season, buf this
year we are to play them first in
the league games. This makes it
necessary to have a strong preliminary schedule, starting about two
weeks earlier than usual.
On the whole, the schedule is
most satisfactory. There are two
more games than usual, and all but .
the Navy and Swarthmore are to
be played at Homewood.
Dr. James Mark Baldwin formerly professor of philosophy in
this University is delivering the
opening series of lectures, in the
New National Uhiversity of Mexico. He will presently publish a
new book: "The Individual. and
Society."

At first glance it would seem
that the fund has not been advancing so rapidly as during previous
weeks. The amount subscribed
being only $3o,000 which brings
the total up to $168,000. There
was only one large subscription,
that of Mr. Henry Walters for
$15,000. But it is only apparently
true that the work on the fund has
been slightly retarded. When the
first half of the fund was completed
ten days ago, the committee announced that it intended to raise
the remaining million, or to be accurate '$900,000, outside of Baltimore. It considered that the citizens of Baltimore had responded
generously enough and that it
would be unfair to ask them to
subscribe the entire amount. Johns
Hopkins is an institution national
in its scope and interests and it
is the nation that should help it in
its time of need. Consequently the
committee has been working elsewhere and the contribution of last
week were the voluntary and unsolicited gifts of our noble citizens.
As announced before Dr. E. R.
L. Gould has been at work in New
York for some time "prospecting."
He has given out nothing definite
but he has hinted at some rich gifts
which were promised toward the
second million. The committee
has been working in other cities
too with more or less success. So
the progress made during the last
ten days which seems at first to
be very little is in fact considerable.
A matter worthy of the highest
praise is the generosity and willingness with which the business men of
Baltimore have bent their energies
to the raising of the fund. Not
only did they give freely of their
means but they organized into a
committee and gave much of their
valuable time to the work of soliciting subscriptions from others. The
women are deserving of no less
praise; the work which was done
by the ladies' committee was admirable. If the results of the
activities of these two committees
were summated it would be found
that, it constitutes a considerable
part of the total. "It is doubtful,"
said President Remsen, "if there
ever was an instance in which the'
citizens of any city showed so intense an -interest in, and so nobly
supported, a • local educational institution."
The general committee has
worked hard. The busy men who

matter. We want to show the
world that the students are in the
movement to help the University.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 9, 1911
PORT ANTONIO TO KINGSTON
Travels of Biologists on the Island of
Jamaica and Early Experiences.
BY .A. R. MIDDLETON AND H. H. YORK
(Continued front No. ix)

The next morning, Tuesday, May
17, about 8 o'clock, our train left
for Kingston, and that was a ride
that I do not think any of us will
soon forget. In the coach in which
we rode, there were no fewer than
nine nationalities of man represented, including Anglo-Saxon(English
and American), Japanese, Chinese,
coolies from India, negroes, mulattoes, and half-breeds between the
Chinaman and negro, between Japanese and coolies, and between the
English and coolies. The coach
was packed. There is an aisle up
the middle of these coaches like
our American day-coaches, but instead of the seats all facing the
same way, they are so arranged that
the first and second seats, the third
and fourth seats face each other.
Most of the men were smoking
cigarettes and pipes, and not a few
of the women were enjoying them.
This kept the car pretty Well filled
with tobacco smoke in spite of the
fact that all the windows were open
and was made rather amusing by two
placards tacked up overthe second
pair of seats from each end on
opposite sides of the car, which
read,"No smoking allowed in these
seats." The scats are wooden
benches much like those seen along
the walks in Druid Hill Park.
Before going further, I. might
mention that all the train hands on
the Jamaica Railway are negroes,
even to the mail clerks.
The line of the railway, after
leaving Port Antonio, travels west
along the seashore for quite a distance, then it crosses over the
mountains of the interior, by passes
and tunnels in a direction a little
west of south, till it reaches Spanish Town, where the branch that
goes to Montego Bay takes a northwesterly course and the main road
turns almost due east through the
lowlands to Kingston. The scenery
between Port Antonio and Spanish
Town simply beggars description;
It is a succession of high mountains
and deep, narrow valleys, all covered with beautiful, living green. The
• fertile valleys, the more gentle
slopes, and the upland plateaus are
all covered with enormous banana
plantations. In making this trip,
suddenly one's train comes around a

bend out on to one of these enormous
table-lands that is as lcvel as a table
top and covered with banana palms.
Right in the middle of it, there juts
up into the air, to possibly one hundred feet, two great coral cliffs,
their perpendicular surfaces looking
like enormous honey-combs.
The Jamaican trains are not provided with dining cars, so, unless
one carries his lunch, he is dependent for what he eats upon negro
women who are to be seen at almost every station along the railway with head baskets or wooden
trays, full of fruit and other eatables. These eatables consist of
pieces of very crude cane sugar,
peppermint candy, ginger bread,
wheat bread in various forms,
which, by the way, the natives esteem quite a luxury, owing to the
fact that the Jamaican import duty
on flour stuffs is thirty-three and
one-third per cent. ad valorem, and
finally a sort of small meat pie, the
filling of which seemed to be a sort
of curry. Most of us decided not
to avail ourselves of the opportunities of purchasing these delicacies.
The fruit offered for sale consisted
largely of mangoes. This fruit was
brought into Jamaica from India
and the East. It is roughly, kidney
shaped, or pear-shaped, and its
pulp, very stringy and of a decided
"turpentine" flavor, is of a golden
yellow color. Fully one-third of its
bulk is occupied by the single seed.
One soon acquires a taste for this
fruit and enjoys eating it very
much. There are quite a number
of varieties of it grown on the
island, the one esteemed the best,
being called "Number Eleven." The
"Number Eleven" is said to get its
name from the fact that a ship
carrying a consignment of seeds
was wrecked on the island, and
when the case was opened it was
found that the packages were numbered and did not have the names of
the fruits on them. These seeds
were planted and the one labeled
"Number Eleven" produced the
mangoes in question.
The trip from Port Antonio to
Kingston takes nearly a whole day,
so that we readied Kingston quite
late in the afternoon, and were glad
to stretch our muscles once more,
and when we reached the Hotel
Myrtle Bank, I am sure that most
of us felt as though we had reached
the conclusion of the first "chapter"
of our Jamaica experiences, and
that we had thoroughly enjoyed it
from start to finish.

PRESIDENT'S REPORT OUT

FRESHMEN GYM. CONTESTS

Reviews Work of the Year with Emphasis on Lectures and Meetings
of Societies.

Sides Engaged in Rivalry for Points to
Win Medals Meet Sophomores
Soon.

The report of President Remsen
for • the academic year ended
August 31, 1910, was issued last
week in the current number of the
Hopkins Circular and a copy will
be sent to every alumnus. The
report reviews in detail the work of
the University, losses and additions
to the academic staff, prizes given,
degrees conferred, gifts received
and the various activities of the
different departments. The latter
information is contained in appended statements from the registrar, departmental heads, librarian,
dean of the medical school and director of the Hopkins Press.
Stress is laid in the report on
the number of popular meetings
and scientific lectures which have
been given in McCoy Hall, either
under the auspices of the University or other organizations. Fifteen non-resident lecturers last year
gave addresses either on the foundations for this purpose or additional courses arranged for by
the University authorities. In ad(lition, under the direction of the
Huxley Societ)7, the Scientific
Association and the Philological
Groups many other scholars addressed the instructors and advanced students interested.
The most important organizations to hold conventions were the
American Philological Association
and the Archxlogical Institute of
America, the American Oriental
Society, the Municipal Art Society,
the Maryland Peace Society, and
the Public School Teachers' Association.
The report of the registrar, which
is attached, reviews at length the
present enrollment and the total:
number of students who have registered at the University during its
34 years of existence. The enrollment figures for the current year
have already been made public in
the Preliminary Register giving the
enrollment in the specific courses.
During the 34 years 6,530 students
have been enrolled. Of these 2,435
are registered from Maryland and
4,095 from 83 other States and
countries.

The freshman gymnasium contest will begin this week, for the
two captains have chosen their
three and twenty "valiant men and
true." The diviions have been
selected evenly so that the contest
may be as close and exciting as
possible. To heighten the interest,
beside the individual medals for the
winning side, three medals will be
given to the winners of the greatest
number of points.
Ever since the Christmas holidays the two squads have been
practicing the more difficult events:
the hop, skip, and jump, and the
window- jumping. The other contests will be in rope—climbing,
push-ups, pull-ups, fence vaulting.,
running high jump with and without the springing board, broad •
jump, club circle pull, 25-yard
dash, tug-of-war, potato race, horse
and rider, and relay race.
As the number of entrants is
large, the meet will probably last
several weeks.
The date has been fixed for the
Freshman-Sophomore class meet.
It will be held on the last Saturday
night in January (the 28th).
There will be four field events:
pole vault, broad jump, high jump,
and shot-put. Among the track
events will be a 30-yard dash, half
mile and mile runs (eighteen laps
to a mile on the "cage" track!).
Although the freshmen have been
kept in training by the gymnasium
class, they are going to take no
chances. So it is expected that they
will begin active training soon.
The meet will undoubtedly be close,
as the sophomores want to blot out
old memories.

A valuable opportunity to hear
a distinguished literary man speak
and to gain information upon an
important public topic will be afforded by the Maryland Peace
Society, which has arranged for an
illustrated lecture on "The History
of the Peace Movement" to be
delivered by Mr. Hamilton Holt,
the editor of the Independent, on
Tuesday, January 10, at 8.30 P.
M., in McCoy Hall. Mr. Holt's
editorials on arbitration and disarmament have brought him and
the Independent into widespread
public notice. His long advocacy.
of international peace qualifies Mr.
Holt to speak authoritatively of the
development of public sentiment
on the question.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 9, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is. always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

January 6, 1911.
To. the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR:—I noticed in your
last issue an appeal to the undergraduate classes to organize in
making class contributions to the
Homewood Fund. I am writing
to tell you of the experience of the
last two graduating classes which
together contributed a one-class
fund.
A committee was organized very
hastily to collect our fund and was
able to interview thirty-two men in
the short time at its disposal. Of
the thirty-two thus interviewed,
twenty-six subscribed, one said that
he would prefer making a substantial contribution later on, another
that his parents had already contributed too large a sum for him to
be able to add to it, and the rest
sorrowfully pleaded guilty to a
temporary lack of funds. I should
like to point out that,with avery few
exceptions,these subscriptions came
from men who were still students
and not, as our graduates have
sometimes been called, "coiningmoney alumni." The average student was found to be able to contribute fifteen dollars in the course
of what is practically four years,
as is allowed under the terms of the
subscription, and it would perhaps
be advisable to call for this amount
from every student here. If this
average were maintained among the
classes, the students at the University would be recorded in the
final tabulation as contributing a
sum which is neither extortionate
nor unreasonable to expect. Besides this, please allow me to suggest, as very recently an undergraduate myself, that an organized response from undergraduate
classes, no matter how insignificant
the total might appear, would at
least demonstrate that the younger
students are as much interested in
the campaign as the oldest alumni
have shown themselves to be.
Yours very truly,
GEORGE ROSS VEAZEY, 'IO.
Senior Class Meeting.

Wins Historical Prize.

The American Historical Association, in its annual meeting held
recently at Indianapolis, gave the
Justin Winsor prize to Edward
Raymond Turner, Ph. D., a graduate of this University who is now
Associate in History at Bryn Mawr
College, for his book entitled "The
Negro in Pennsylvania—Slavery,
Servitude, Freedom."
The Justin Winsor prize, which
is in many respects the most important prize awarded in this
country for work in American
history, is now given every two
years in recognition of the most
valuable and original work done in
American history by an author
whose reputation is not yet established. The prize has been awarded
nine times since 1896.
Dr. Turner's book is the most
exhaustive study of the rise and
progress of the negro in any particular locality yet written. Its purpose is to trace the normal development of the status of the negro in
a typical district of the United
States, and to show what course
that development is apt to take
when not violently interferred with.
as it was, for example, in the South
after the Civil War. • This book
contains, perhaps, the first important historical treatment of the free
negro.
The work is constructed entirely
from public documents, manuscripts, contemporary pamphlets
and newspapers. The material was
obtained for the most part in Pennsylvania, especially from the collection of the State Library at Harrisburg, the Historical Society of
Pennsylvania and the'Library -Company of Philadelphia.

Prominent Alumnus Dies.

At the comparatively young age
of 41, Dr. Bernwick B. Lanier,
surgeon, author, and formerly a
member of the Faculty of the University of Maryland succumbed to
liver trouble on January first. Dr.
Lanier received the A. B. degree
at this University in 1890. Interested in lacrosse while at college,
be followed the game long after
'graduation, even when unable to
take an active part himself. He
was descended from well-known
-surgeons which explains his taste
in that direction. This taste was
cultivated by his association with
Dr. William E. Halstead while
studying, and Dr. Louis McLane
Tiffany while practicing surgery.

ALUMNI NOTES

Last week Mr. Benjamin wass
delegated by the Pennsylvania
University Chess Club to come to
Baltimore and arrange a match
with the Johns Hopkins team. It
has been two years since the two
teams have played against each
other, the last match being won
by Pennsylvania. This last match
was the first to be played under a
four-year agreement under which
the matches were to be played alternately at Baltimore and Philadelphia, the visitors paying traveling expenses and being entertained
by the hoine team. Last year no
overtures were made by Pennsylvania and as the Chess Club at
Hopkins was dormant the matter
was allowed to lapse. This year
probably a team of six men will go
to Philadelphia to play the match
there. No date has been set but
it will be about the first of February.
At a meeting of the executive
committee on Thursday last it was
decided to assess each member
of the club twenty-five cents to pay
the expenses of the trip in case that
the treasury was low. Mr. W. E.
Pearce, Jr., was elected captain of
the chess team.
The prospects for a victory over
Pennsylvania are not bright and
the men would be highly elated if
they got a draw. Mr. Benjamin
is the fourth man on the Pennsylvania team and he was easily defeated by the fourth choice for the
gokins team when he was heie.
The unexpected may happen.

THE NEWS r=ED LKITER

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 9, 1911.

DR. HOWELL RESIGNS AS DEAN

TRIANGULAR DEBATE LEAGUE

LACROSSE SCHEDULE COMPLETED

GAINING SECOND WIND

Retains Chair of Physiology, However,
and His Place is Taken by
Professor Williams.

Hopkins, Gettysburg and Washington
and Lee to Meet in Platform Contests Under New Agreement.

Indians Take Last Open Date, Assuring
Unusually Interesting Season.

Committee Renewing Efforts to Complete Second Million by a Vigorous
Campaign.

After eleven years of service
Dr. William Henry Howell has resigned as Dean of the Medical
School. His resignation has been
accepted by the trustees. Dr. J.
Whitridge Williams, professor of
obstetrics, has already taken up Dr.
Howell's duties. The latter will,
however, retain the chair of physiology which he has held since
1894.
The announcement of the resignation does not come as a surprise,
as the intimate friends of the dean
have known for some time that he
was seriously contemplating resigning. The combined duties of
the two positions were felt by Dr.
Howell to be too exacting, and he
tendered his resignation in order
to have more time to devote to his
work as professor of physiology.
President Remsen stated that he
was sorry to lose Dr. Howell, but
that he would continue on the staff.
Dr. Howell is a Baltimorean by
birth and received his preliminary
education in the public schools of
Baltimore. He received his bachelor's and doctor's degrees from
Hopkins, and in 1888 was appointed associate professor of
physiology. In the early nineties
he served on the staffs of the University of Michigan and Harvard
University, but returned to Hopkins in 1894 to become professor
of physiology. In 1899 he was
made dean.
Dr. Williams is also a Hopkins alumnus and is president of
the alumni association. He received his degree of doctor of
medicine, however, from the University of Maryland. He has spent
several years abroad and since 1889
has been collected with the medical
school. Dr. Williams is an attractive lecturer and is noted for the
amusing incidents and anecdotes
from his own personal experience
which lie intersperses in his explanations to his classes.

Additional opportunities for intercollegiate debating will be afforded Hopkins students by the inauguration this year of a triangular
league between this University,
Gettysburg College and Washington and Lee University.
Last year's victory at Lexington completed the series in which
Hopkins and Washington and Lee
had been engaged, and left both
institutions free to arrange new
contests. Dr. French and the committee corresponded with a number
of colleges with a view to entering
some kind of a triangular agreement. The expense of sending a
team far from Baltimore prevented
contests with some institutions,
while others were already engaged
in leagues among themselves.
In the selection of Gettysburg
as one of the opponents, its intimate
relations with Hopkins in the past
were taken into account. With the
single exception of Yale, Gettysburg has sent more graduates to
pursue advanced studies here than
has any other college. Washington and Lee was taken on largely
because of the desire of the defeated Virginians for an opportunity for revenge.
One difficulty in arranging the
terms of the agreement arose from
the desire of the Washington and
Lee authorities to put their law
students on the team. Both of the
other schools wished to limit the
contest to undergraduates and objected to meeting the law men.
The usual arrangements of triangular debates will govern the
contests. Each institution will be
represented by two teams of three
men each, one of which will debate
at home and the other abroad.
Thus each college debates both of
the others each year. The same
question is argued at all three institutions on the same night, and
each school upholds both sides, the
affirmative by one team and the
negative by the other.
New interest will doubtless be
taken in intercollegiate debating
here as a result of the new system.
Six places will be open to speakers
instead of three as heretofore, and
there must be twice as many alternates and advisers. This will demand the development of new debaters and will test the ability of
the undergraduates on the platform. More candidates for the
debating teams must apply in order
to turn out two winning teams.

The Dance.

The date of the second of the
series of dances to be given by the
Cotillion Club, which was announced for February 3rd, has been
changed to Saturday, January 28th.
The third dance will be given
Saturday, April 22nd. , It is hoped
that as many men as possible will
make a point of attending these
dances , and help to make them a
success.

The last open date on the lacrosse schedule, Saturday, April 22,
has now been filled. Manager
Makel has made arrangements with
the Carlisle Indians for a game to
be played at Homewood, and this
game completes the schedule.
The Indian game will come on the
Saturday before the Swarthmore
game and it is in a way significant
that the Indians are considered not
too strong to be played only 4. week
before the game which will in all
probability decide the intercollegiate championship of the United
States. Hopkins has games sched'tiled with three of the four teams
of the northern division of the
league and victories over these
teams are practically certain to include a victory over the champions
of this division. This schedule
with the northern team is rather
unusual for Hopkins. We play
Harvard regularly when their team
comes south in the spring, but
Cornell and Columbia have not
played in Baltimore for several
years.
, There will be only one disappointment for lacrosse enthusiasts
in Baltimore this year—the lack of
a game between the 'Varsity and
Mt. Washington. The Mt. Washington game always arouses great
interest and many will be sorry
not to have it this year.
The schedule this year is very
early, owing to the chancing of
the league schedule. Heretofore
we have played Swarthmore as the
last game in the season, buf this
year we are to play them first in
the league games. This makes it
necessary to have a strong preliminary schedule, starting about two
weeks earlier than usual.
On the whole, the schedule is
most satisfactory. There are two
more games than usual, and all but .
the Navy and Swarthmore are to
be played at Homewood.
Dr. James Mark Baldwin formerly professor of philosophy in
this University is delivering the
opening series of lectures, in the
New National Uhiversity of Mexico. He will presently publish a
new book: "The Individual. and
Society."

At first glance it would seem
that the fund has not been advancing so rapidly as during previous
weeks. The amount subscribed
being only $3o,000 which brings
the total up to $168,000. There
was only one large subscription,
that of Mr. Henry Walters for
$15,000. But it is only apparently
true that the work on the fund has
been slightly retarded. When the
first half of the fund was completed
ten days ago, the committee announced that it intended to raise
the remaining million, or to be accurate '$900,000, outside of Baltimore. It considered that the citizens of Baltimore had responded
generously enough and that it
would be unfair to ask them to
subscribe the entire amount. Johns
Hopkins is an institution national
in its scope and interests and it
is the nation that should help it in
its time of need. Consequently the
committee has been working elsewhere and the contribution of last
week were the voluntary and unsolicited gifts of our noble citizens.
As announced before Dr. E. R.
L. Gould has been at work in New
York for some time "prospecting."
He has given out nothing definite
but he has hinted at some rich gifts
which were promised toward the
second million. The committee
has been working in other cities
too with more or less success. So
the progress made during the last
ten days which seems at first to
be very little is in fact considerable.
A matter worthy of the highest
praise is the generosity and willingness with which the business men of
Baltimore have bent their energies
to the raising of the fund. Not
only did they give freely of their
means but they organized into a
committee and gave much of their
valuable time to the work of soliciting subscriptions from others. The
women are deserving of no less
praise; the work which was done
by the ladies' committee was admirable. If the results of the
activities of these two committees
were summated it would be found
that, it constitutes a considerable
part of the total. "It is doubtful,"
said President Remsen, "if there
ever was an instance in which the'
citizens of any city showed so intense an -interest in, and so nobly
supported, a • local educational institution."

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 9, 1911
PORT ANTONIO TO KINGSTON
Travels of Biologists on the Island of
Jamaica and Early Experiences.
BY .A. R. MIDDLETON AND H. H. YORK
(Continued front No. ix)

The next morning, Tuesday, May
17, about 8 o'clock, our train left
for Kingston, and that was a ride
that I do not think any of us will
soon forget. In the coach in which
we rode, there were no fewer than
nine nationalities of man represented, including Anglo-Saxon(English
and American), Japanese, Chinese,
coolies from India, negroes, mulattoes, and half-breeds between the
Chinaman and negro, between Japanese and coolies, and between the
English and coolies. The coach
was packed. There is an aisle up
the middle of these coaches like
our American day-coaches, but instead of the seats all facing the
same way, they are so arranged that
the first and second seats, the third
and fourth seats face each other.
Most of the men were smoking
cigarettes and pipes, and not a few
of the women were enjoying them.
This kept the car pretty Well filled
with tobacco smoke in spite of the
fact that all the windows were open
and was made rather amusing by two
placards tacked up overthe second
pair of seats from each end on
opposite sides of the car, which
read,"No smoking allowed in these
seats." The scats are wooden
benches much like those seen along
the walks in Druid Hill Park.
Before going further, I. might
mention that all the train hands on
the Jamaica Railway are negroes,
even to the mail clerks.
The line of the railway, after
leaving Port Antonio, travels west
along the seashore for quite a distance, then it crosses over the
mountains of the interior, by passes
and tunnels in a direction a little
west of south, till it reaches Spanish Town, where the branch that
goes to Montego Bay takes a northwesterly course and the main road
turns almost due east through the
lowlands to Kingston. The scenery
between Port Antonio and Spanish
Town simply beggars description;
It is a succession of high mountains
and deep, narrow valleys, all covered with beautiful, living green. The
• fertile valleys, the more gentle
slopes, and the upland plateaus are
all covered with enormous banana
plantations. In making this trip,
suddenly one's train comes around a

bend out on to one of these enormous
table-lands that is as lcvel as a table
top and covered with banana palms.
Right in the middle of it, there juts
up into the air, to possibly one hundred feet, two great coral cliffs,
their perpendicular surfaces looking
like enormous honey-combs.
The Jamaican trains are not provided with dining cars, so, unless
one carries his lunch, he is dependent for what he eats upon negro
women who are to be seen at almost every station along the railway with head baskets or wooden
trays, full of fruit and other eatables. These eatables consist of
pieces of very crude cane sugar,
peppermint candy, ginger bread,
wheat bread in various forms,
which, by the way, the natives esteem quite a luxury, owing to the
fact that the Jamaican import duty
on flour stuffs is thirty-three and
one-third per cent. ad valorem, and
finally a sort of small meat pie, the
filling of which seemed to be a sort
of curry. Most of us decided not
to avail ourselves of the opportunities of purchasing these delicacies.
The fruit offered for sale consisted
largely of mangoes. This fruit was
brought into Jamaica from India
and the East. It is roughly, kidney
shaped, or pear-shaped, and its
pulp, very stringy and of a decided
"turpentine" flavor, is of a golden
yellow color. Fully one-third of its
bulk is occupied by the single seed.
One soon acquires a taste for this
fruit and enjoys eating it very
much. There are quite a number
of varieties of it grown on the
island, the one esteemed the best,
being called "Number Eleven." The
"Number Eleven" is said to get its
name from the fact that a ship
carrying a consignment of seeds
was wrecked on the island, and
when the case was opened it was
found that the packages were numbered and did not have the names of
the fruits on them. These seeds
were planted and the one labeled
"Number Eleven" produced the
mangoes in question.
The trip from Port Antonio to
Kingston takes nearly a whole day,
so that we readied Kingston quite
late in the afternoon, and were glad
to stretch our muscles once more,
and when we reached the Hotel
Myrtle Bank, I am sure that most
of us felt as though we had reached
the conclusion of the first "chapter"
of our Jamaica experiences, and
that we had thoroughly enjoyed it
from start to finish.

PRESIDENT'S REPORT OUT

FRESHMEN GYM. CONTESTS

Reviews Work of the Year with Emphasis on Lectures and Meetings
of Societies.

Sides Engaged in Rivalry for Points to
Win Medals Meet Sophomores
Soon.

The report of President Remsen
for • the academic year ended
August 31, 1910, was issued last
week in the current number of the
Hopkins Circular and a copy will
be sent to every alumnus. The
report reviews in detail the work of
the University, losses and additions
to the academic staff, prizes given,
degrees conferred, gifts received
and the various activities of the
different departments. The latter
information is contained in appended statements from the registrar, departmental heads, librarian,
dean of the medical school and director of the Hopkins Press.
Stress is laid in the report on
the number of popular meetings
and scientific lectures which have
been given in McCoy Hall, either
under the auspices of the University or other organizations. Fifteen non-resident lecturers last year
gave addresses either on the foundations for this purpose or additional courses arranged for by
the University authorities. In ad(lition, under the direction of the
Huxley Societ)7, the Scientific
Association and the Philological
Groups many other scholars addressed the instructors and advanced students interested.
The most important organizations to hold conventions were the
American Philological Association
and the Archxlogical Institute of
America, the American Oriental
Society, the Municipal Art Society,
the Maryland Peace Society, and
the Public School Teachers' Association.
The report of the registrar, which
is attached, reviews at length the
present enrollment and the total:
number of students who have registered at the University during its
34 years of existence. The enrollment figures for the current year
have already been made public in
the Preliminary Register giving the
enrollment in the specific courses.
During the 34 years 6,530 students
have been enrolled. Of these 2,435
are registered from Maryland and
4,095 from 83 other States and
countries.

The freshman gymnasium contest will begin this week, for the
two captains have chosen their
three and twenty "valiant men and
true." The diviions have been
selected evenly so that the contest
may be as close and exciting as
possible. To heighten the interest,
beside the individual medals for the
winning side, three medals will be
given to the winners of the greatest
number of points.
Ever since the Christmas holidays the two squads have been
practicing the more difficult events:
the hop, skip, and jump, and the
window- jumping. The other contests will be in rope—climbing,
push-ups, pull-ups, fence vaulting.,
running high jump with and without the springing board, broad •
jump, club circle pull, 25-yard
dash, tug-of-war, potato race, horse
and rider, and relay race.
As the number of entrants is
large, the meet will probably last
several weeks.
The date has been fixed for the
Freshman-Sophomore class meet.
It will be held on the last Saturday
night in January (the 28th).
There will be four field events:
pole vault, broad jump, high jump,
and shot-put. Among the track
events will be a 30-yard dash, half
mile and mile runs (eighteen laps
to a mile on the "cage" track!).
Although the freshmen have been
kept in training by the gymnasium
class, they are going to take no
chances. So it is expected that they
will begin active training soon.
The meet will undoubtedly be close,
as the sophomores want to blot out
old memories.

THE NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 9, 1911
COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is. always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged to
make use of this column.)

January 6, 1911.
To. the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.
DEAR SIR:—I noticed in your
last issue an appeal to the undergraduate classes to organize in
making class contributions to the
Homewood Fund. I am writing
to tell you of the experience of the
last two graduating classes which
together contributed a one-class
fund.
A committee was organized very
hastily to collect our fund and was
able to interview thirty-two men in
the short time at its disposal. Of
the thirty-two thus interviewed,
twenty-six subscribed, one said that
he would prefer making a substantial contribution later on, another
that his parents had already contributed too large a sum for him to
be able to add to it, and the rest
sorrowfully pleaded guilty to a
temporary lack of funds. I should
like to point out that,with avery few
exceptions,these subscriptions came
from men who were still students
and not, as our graduates have
sometimes been called, "coiningmoney alumni." The average student was found to be able to contribute fifteen dollars in the course
of what is practically four years,
as is allowed under the terms of the
subscription, and it would perhaps
be advisable to call for this amount
from every student here. If this
average were maintained among the
classes, the students at the University would be recorded in the
final tabulation as contributing a
sum which is neither extortionate
nor unreasonable to expect. Besides this, please allow me to suggest, as very recently an undergraduate myself, that an organized response from undergraduate
classes, no matter how insignificant
the total might appear, would at
least demonstrate that the younger
students are as much interested in
the campaign as the oldest alumni
have shown themselves to be.
Yours very truly,
GEORGE ROSS VEAZEY, 'IO.
Senior Class Meeting.

Wins Historical Prize.

The American Historical Association, in its annual meeting held
recently at Indianapolis, gave the
Justin Winsor prize to Edward
Raymond Turner, Ph. D., a graduate of this University who is now
Associate in History at Bryn Mawr
College, for his book entitled "The
Negro in Pennsylvania—Slavery,
Servitude, Freedom."
The Justin Winsor prize, which
is in many respects the most important prize awarded in this
country for work in American
history, is now given every two
years in recognition of the most
valuable and original work done in
American history by an author
whose reputation is not yet established. The prize has been awarded
nine times since 1896.
Dr. Turner's book is the most
exhaustive study of the rise and
progress of the negro in any particular locality yet written. Its purpose is to trace the normal development of the status of the negro in
a typical district of the United
States, and to show what course
that development is apt to take
when not violently interferred with.
as it was, for example, in the South
after the Civil War. • This book
contains, perhaps, the first important historical treatment of the free
negro.
The work is constructed entirely
from public documents, manuscripts, contemporary pamphlets
and newspapers. The material was
obtained for the most part in Pennsylvania, especially from the collection of the State Library at Harrisburg, the Historical Society of
Pennsylvania and the'Library -Company of Philadelphia.

CIGARETTES

Prominent Alumnus Dies.

At the comparatively young age
of 41, Dr. Bernwick B. Lanier,
surgeon, author, and formerly a
member of the Faculty of the University of Maryland succumbed to
liver trouble on January first. Dr.
Lanier received the A. B. degree
at this University in 1890. Interested in lacrosse while at college,
be followed the game long after
'graduation, even when unable to
take an active part himself. He
was descended from well-known
-surgeons which explains his taste
in that direction. This taste was
cultivated by his association with
Dr. William E. Halstead while
studying, and Dr. Louis McLane
Tiffany while practicing surgery.

ALUMNI NOTES

Last week Mr. Benjamin wass
delegated by the Pennsylvania
University Chess Club to come to
Baltimore and arrange a match
with the Johns Hopkins team. It
has been two years since the two
teams have played against each
other, the last match being won
by Pennsylvania. This last match
was the first to be played under a
four-year agreement under which
the matches were to be played alternately at Baltimore and Philadelphia, the visitors paying traveling expenses and being entertained
by the hoine team. Last year no
overtures were made by Pennsylvania and as the Chess Club at
Hopkins was dormant the matter
was allowed to lapse. This year
probably a team of six men will go
to Philadelphia to play the match
there. No date has been set but
it will be about the first of February.
At a meeting of the executive
committee on Thursday last it was
decided to assess each member
of the club twenty-five cents to pay
the expenses of the trip in case that
the treasury was low. Mr. W. E.
Pearce, Jr., was elected captain of
the chess team.
The prospects for a victory over
Pennsylvania are not bright and
the men would be highly elated if
they got a draw. Mr. Benjamin
is the fourth man on the Pennsylvania team and he was easily defeated by the fourth choice for the
gokins team when he was heie.
The unexpected may happen.
